International A3-13 Attempts to close the P.L.O mission to the United Nations by the United States have created a dispute that must be submitted to arbitration, the World Court ruled in a setback for the Reagan Aministration. Page A1 Seoul's ruling party lost a majority in the National Assembly as the opposition made strong gains in the legislative elections despite bitter divisions. The party headed by Kim Dae Jung was the biggest gainer. A1 Moonshining in the Soviet Union has forced authorities to ration sugar in some parts of the country to fight it and caused sugar shortages in others. Sugar rationing and shortages have angered consumers. A8 Kabul held a Soviet-style parade to mark the tenth anniversary of its revolution. Moscow sent a low-level delegation, a Western diplomat said, as a sign that it is distancing itself from the rulers it helped install. A1 News analysis: U.S.-Soviet talks on a new strategic arms treaty made enough progress recently to suggest that negotiations are gradually moving forward. But it is unlikely that a pact will be completed this year. A12 Two Israeli soldiers were killed in a shootout that also left three Palestinian guerrillas dead. An Israeli patrol discovered the guerrillas infiltrating from Lebanon, the army said. A10 Israel took the press credentials of two foreign correspondents, from The Washington Post and NBC News, as punishment for reports that had not been submitted to a military censor. A10 A program to resettle Vietnamese, most from the overcrowded north, to less developed areas has led to tremendous hardships for people. Planned population movements have a disastrous history in Vietnam. A3 An offer for a British confectioner, Rowntree P.L.C., was rejected. The $3.95 billion bid by Nestle S.A. of Switzerland for the maker of the Kit Kat bar is the largest by a foreign company for a British concern. D1 U.S. bars plan on acid rain A5 Soviet TV shows Armenian riots A12 Visiting U.S. aide condemns Mozambique rebels A13 National A16-25, B10-11 The economy grew by 2.3 percent in the first quater of 1988 as spending by businesses and consumers rebounded from a sluggish fall pace, the Government reported, easing fears of a recession. A1 The special prosecutor law is under review by the Supreme Court, which heard arguments on its constitutionality in an unusually long session that gave no indication of how the Justices would rule. A1 Oliver North's private diaries were subpoenaed by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which is investigating international drug smuggling and wants to examine the notes in uncensored form. A18 The distribution of Accutane, an acne drug linked to birth defects, should be restricted, a Federal panel recommended. The restrictions would be the first applied to a drug already approved for marketing. A17 St. Louis journal: Stadium plans turn to soybean seed A16 Anger in Ohio over a death camp conviction A21 Politics A24-25 Michael Dukakis took Pennsylvania, trouncing Jesse Jackson in the Democratic Presidential primary and tightening his grip on the nomination. A1 Vice President Bush won overwhelmingly in Pennsylvania and closed in on the number of delegates needed to clinch the Republican Presidential nomination. A1 Jesse Jackson took up South Africa in discussions with members of Congress, State Deparment officials and representatives of southern African States in Washington before resuming his Presidential campaign in Ohio. A24 Black voters in Pennsylvania cheered on Jesse Jackson despite saying he was not likely to win the Democratic Presidential nomination. His campaign was disappointed at a smaller turnout than had been hoped for. A24 Senator Bob Dole critized coverage of all the campaigns by television and the press, but did not blame press coverage for his loss to Vice President Bush in the Republican Presidential race. A25 Washington Talk A22 Navy fires a volley of self-congratulation Regional B1-6 Mayor Koch was criticized by Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, the city's highest-ranking black appointee, who said the Mayor should apologize for his attacks on Jesse Jackson before the New York Presidential Primary election. A1 Homeless veterans need more help than Ronald Foreman, of the Salvation Army, thought when he opened New York City's first shelter for veterans last fall. He found that many need more than a job and a place to live. B1 Inadequate maintenance of a bridge in upstate New York, the Schoharie Creek bridge on the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, was the probable cause of its collapse, according to the National Transportation Safety Board. B1 A security guard accused of murder at the Brooklyn shopping mall he pa trolled had served 18 months in prison for robbery. But a state agency was prohibited from telling the agency that hired him of his conviction. B1 A hospital in Queens will be cut off from Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement in June, according to Federal officials. Inspectors found violations in 11 areas at the Parsons Hospital in Flushing, Queens.
